turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Perhaps you're just polishing a stone, endowing this Elephant Man with qualities he doesn't possess?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: And what qualities are those? Intelligence or stupidity?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I'm sure I don't know, Freddie.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I'm sorry... I don't know either. I just don't know.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Well, these things take time.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I've only got until two o'clock tomorrow afternoon, when Carr Gomm meets him. Somehow, between now and then I've got to make John Merrick at least seem like an intelligent man... Why am I fooling myself? Nothing short of John delivering the Sermon on the Mount is going to sway Carr Gomm...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John loves the house.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: And here are my mother and father.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You stay with me.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Dinner will be served, shortly, dear.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: More romances for John?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Hmmm?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: ...Freddie! What's the matter? You've been like this all evening.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Oh... I've just been thinking about something that man Bytes said.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, Freddie. What could that wretched vampire say to upset you?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: That I am very little different from him.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh that's absurd, Frederick. No, no Frederick, that's all wrong! John is happier and more fulfilled now than he has ever been in his entire life. And, that is completely due to you.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: But why did I do it? What was this all for? So John Merrick could live out his last days in peace and comfort? Or so I could become famous?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Frederick, just what is it that you are saying?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: ...Am I a good man or am I a bad man?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh Frederick.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Excuse me, Mr. Treves, sir.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I found it.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Did you see it?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Our man is sick. Come right away.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Like this.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I'll get my bag.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: You sly bastard. You're doing this to spite me, aren't you!

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Aw, Bytes, he's sick.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: He's doing it to spite me, I tell you, and it's got to stop!

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: He's sick, Bytes. He's going to die.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: If he does it's his own fault! But I'm not burying that swollen bag of flesh.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: I'll show you! I'll show you!

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Don't!

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: What did you do to him? He's been like this all night!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: He was fine when he left here, and now look at him.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I intend to.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: He fell.  He falls.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: He must have taken quite a fall.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: He's a clumsy git. Never watches where he is going.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Why is he sitting up like this? He needs rest.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: That's the way he sleeps. If he lays down, he'll die.  Head's too heavy.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: This man belongs in hospital.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: Can't you fix him up here? ...He's my livelihood. Listen.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You listen, you're not going to have much of a livelihood if this man dies. He's got the rale, he's very weak, and I don't know how much damage has been done by his "fall". Now stop wasting time and fetch a cab.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: I like doing business with you. You and I understand each other, completely. I know I can trust you. Can't I?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Everything will be seen to.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: I want my man back.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Just a moment, how did you get in here?

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: Never mind that, I want my man!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: He's still very sick. Please come downstairs with me. I'll explain the situation.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: DON'T... Don't muck me about. You've had plenty of time to fix him up, and he's leaving with me, NOW. Do you understand me? Now, Mr. Treves. We had a bargain!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You misunderstood. This man suffered a severe fall, if you take my meaning. He's my patient now and I must do what...

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: Pull the other one, why don't you! We made a deal!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I know what you've done to him and he's never going back to that.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: He's a freak! That's how they live. We're partners, him and I, business partners. You're willfully deprivin' me of my livlihood!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: All you do is profit from another man's misery!

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: You think you're better 'n me? YOU wanted the freak to show all your doctor chums and make a name for yourself, you guv. So I gave him to you. On trust, in the name of science! And now I want him back.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You don't own this man!

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: I want him back!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: So you can beat him? So you can starve him? A dog in the street would fare better with you!

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: I've got my rights, damn you, and I'm going to the authorities!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Now I think we really do understand one another.

turns.speaker: BYTES
turns.text: Right... Right.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Good morning, Treves.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Good morning, sir.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: You've acquired a taste for this?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: It's quite nutritious, sir.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Don't be mad. This muck can kill you.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Don't be frightened. He won't hurt you.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Indeed!

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: A hospital is no place for secrecy, Mr. Treves. Doctors spiriting hooded figures about are liable to cause comment. Why wasn't this patient properly admitted, and why is he in isolation? Is he contagious?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No sir, he's got bronchitis and he's been badly beaten.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Why isn't he in the General Ward, then?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Well sir, he's quite seriously deformed, and I fear the other patients would find him... rather shocking.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Deformed? Is that it. Then am I to assume that he is ultimately incurable?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: What are your plans then, Treves... You are aware that the London does not accept incurables. The rules are quite clear on that point.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, I'm well aware of that. But this case is quite exceptional.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Oh, is he a friend of yours?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No, more of an acquaintance.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: I certainly sympathize with your problem, Treves... Why don't you try the British Home, or the Royal Hospital for perhaps they would have a place for him.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes sir, I'll look into that.  Would you like to meet him sir?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Have you contacted the British Home and the Royal Hospital?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Ah, no sir. I had planned to see them in the morning.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Good! How is the patient?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: He's doing very well. In fact that's why I came to see you. I think that if I were to present Mr. Merrick to the hospital committee, then they would have a chance to see for themselves not only the extraordinary nature of the disease, but of the man as well. If the committee had a chance to speak with him, hear him say a few words for himself, I'm sure they would see him as a patient, rather than as a violation of the rules.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: A few words? I thought he was imbecile?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Well sir, perhaps I should explain...

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: I really don't think that's necessary Treves. I'm quite sure the committee will be able to make an equitable decision on the merits of the case, such as they are.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I don't agree. No one can make a reasonable decision about this man's future without at least meeting him. No doctor would presume to diagnose a patient he had never met.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: No, Treves, it's out of the question. Now if it was up to me, I'd say "Certainly, let's meet the fellow, by all means," I'm sorry, I simply can't speak for the other members of the committee.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Then will you meet him, as a representative of the committee.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Mr. Treves, it's out of the question. I want to hear as soon as possible what the other hospitals can do. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Singularly unpleasant chap... uh... I don't suppose there would be any harm in my meeting your... patient, Mr. Treves.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Thank you very much Sir. Shall we say in a few days then?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Shall we say two o'clock tomorrow afternoon?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Wh... whatever is most convenient for you, sir.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Two o'clock then... you know Treves... It seems this acquaintance of yours has become rather more than just an acquaintance.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: ...Yes, Sir.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: It's only a physical problem. He has trouble with certain sounds because of the constrictive deformity of the mouth. But he can talk, and has a great eagerness to make contact with people who will let him. So if you have any difficulty understanding what he is saying, just tell me and I'll make it clear.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Speaking is one thing, Treves, but can the man comprehend?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: ...As I said, it's only a physical problem... but I do feel that Mr. Merrick is very flattered that you're taking the time and trouble to meet him, and he's most anxious to make a good impression, so he might seem rather nervous.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: He needn't. I have no desire to cause him any discomfort. Did you make those inquiries we spoke about?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, I spoke to both the British Home and Royal Hospital for Incurables. I'm afraid that they weren't very encouraging, but they said they'd bring it up at their next committee meeting, so we should have their answers shortly.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Fine, fine. You know, your dedication to this patient is an inspiring thing, Treves. But you must remember that this is a hospital, and there are many patients here. Patients who can be made well, and you owe them your first consideration. Just don't become so obsessed, old man, that you begin to neglect them.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Oh yes?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: And what was that, John?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: It was a nice try, Treves, but the man is so obviously mouthing your words.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, I'm very sorry to have wasted your time, sir. I just felt that I had to do anything I could to protect him.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: I'm sorry too. He simply doesn't belong here. He's be much happier somewhere else, where he could be constantly looked after. Believe me, Frederick, it's better that it worked out this way. Good day.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: How did you, know the rest? I never taught you the rest of it.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Tell me, John, how did you know the rest of the 23rd Psalm?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Treves. Well done.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Not me, sir. Mr. Merrick. He succeeded in spite of my shortsightedness.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Can you imagine what his life has been like?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, I think I can.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: No you can't. You can't begin to know, no one can.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: You are quite right, Treves, this is an exceptional case. And I quite agree that the committee should see Mr. Merrick.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I could easily arrange...

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: No, not that way. Broadneck and the others don't like to deal with patients directly. It makes them queasy... Do you have any photographs of Mr. Merrick?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Well, yes.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Excellent. We shall present them, along with the other particulars of the case to the committee. I want them to see, exactly, how horribly his body has been affected. You and I shall vouch for his inner qualities.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Do you think they'll go along with us?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Of course they will. They're reasonable men.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Don't we?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No, we don't. Their committees have informed me that they're unwilling to take Mr. Merrick, even if they were supplied with funds. They don't want him.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Well, it's up to us then, isn't it?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Has the response picked up?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Frankly, Treves, it's not what I'd expected. A few small cheques. Well- wishers. Don't worry, these things undoubtedly take time.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: But he's so afraid he's going to be carted off. I've promised him that won't happen.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Well... I'll let you know if there's something in the afternoon post.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Please do.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Don't you think this is a bit premature? We don't have the backing yet to...

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Steady on, Treves. Have a seat.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: How are you feeling today?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I feel much better. Thank you for asking. And you?

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: I'm feeling very fit, thank you. How is your bronchitis?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I feel much better. Thank you.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Are you comfortable here?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Everyone has been very kind. I am extremely grateful.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: ...I... everyone has been very kind to me.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Of course. How long did you and Mr. Treves prepare for this interview?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: ...everyone has been very kind.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: Yes, of course... Well, it's been a pleasure meeting you, Mr. Merrick. Good day.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: What is it, Treves?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies, Thou anointest my head with oil...

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: It was a great pleasure to meet you, Mr. Merrick.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I am very pleased to meet you.

turns.speaker: CARR
turns.text: I hope we can talk together again sometime. Good day.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: How long has this man been here?

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: Three quarters of an hour.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Mmmm. Hodges, Pierce come closer. Mr. Hill, take hold of the rope please. It's a machine accident. I expect you'll be seeing a good deal of this.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Abominable things these machines. One can't reason with them.

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: What a mess.

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: I say Freddie, what are you about?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Oh nothing... nothing of any great importance.

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: Good Lord, Freddie! What have you got in there?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You'll know presently. At the meeting of the society. But until then, I beg of you Fox, keep it to yourself.

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: Certainly, if you insist. You must have quite a find there.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I don't know what I've got.

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: Nothing of any importance, eh?

turns.speaker: FOX
turns.text: You never mentioned his mental state.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: He's imbecile, no doubt from birth. He speaks, but... it's all gibberish. No, the man's a homeless idiot...  I pray God he's an idiot.

turns.speaker: K. HEN
turns.text: Fair Katharine, and most fair, will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms Such as will enter at a lady's ear And plead his love-suit to her gentle heart?

turns.speaker: KATH
turns.text: Your majesty shall mock at me; I cannot speak your England.

turns.speaker: K. HEN
turns.text: O fair Katharine, if you will love me soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue. Do you like me, Kate?

turns.speaker: KATH
turns.text: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is "like me".

turns.speaker: K. HEN
turns.text: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.

turns.speaker: KATH
turns.text: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de tramperies.

turns.speaker: K. HEN
turns.text: What say you, fair one? That the tongues of men are full of deceits?

turns.speaker: KATH
turns.text: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits.

turns.speaker: K. HEN
turns.text: I know no way to mince it in love, but directly to say "I love you". What! A speaker is but a prater; a rhyme is but a ballad. A good leg will fall; a straight back will stoop; a black beard will turn white; a curl'd pate will grow bald; a fair face will wither; a full eye will wax hollow; but a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or rather the sun and not the moon; for it shines bright and never changes, but keeps his course truly.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Good day...!

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: I've brought you some things. I hope you'll like, Mr. Merrick. I hope you don't think it too forward.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh, no.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: I knew you'd understand. Here.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: I want you to know that I don't go about giving my pictures to just anyone.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh, no. I would never think it! It's so beautiful. You are so... I'll give it a place of honor, here, next to my mother.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: She's very pretty, your mother.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mr. Treves says that you are in the theatre. Do you live there?

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. I just work there.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Well, even to work there would be wonderful. Is it beautiful?

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: You've never been?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Alas, no.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Well you must go. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth. Of course, I'm rather partial.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Tell me about it, please!

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: It's very difficult to put into a nutshell, but I should say the theater is the shrine of the imagination, where one may suspend disbelief and travel anywhere in the world, to any time you desire. You may look over the shoulders of kings, unobserved, battle with ruthless tyrants, and marry the beautiful princess, all in the space of a few hours. Onstage you may be whoever you wish to be, do anything you please, and always, always live happily ever after. The theatre is all the brightest and best things of the world, Mr. Merrick. It is lights and music, gaiety and joy. It's... well, it's romance.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Romance!

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: That's one thing the theatre has in great store. which reminds me. I have something else for you...

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Have you read it?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: No, but I certainly shall.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do. They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Why, Mr. Merrick, you're not an Elephant Man at all...

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh no?

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Oh no... no... you're a Romeo.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John, I'd like you to meet one of the brightest lights of the British stage, Mrs. Kendal. Mrs. Kendal, John Merrick.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Good day, Mr. Merrick.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: It's all arranged. I'll send over some evening gowns for the sisters that you select to accompany Mr. Merrick. You'll be using the Royal entrance and Princess Alexandra herself will be there to welcome him to her private box.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I'm very grateful to you, Mrs. Kendal. This is just the thing to help him forget his ordeal. John will be very excited.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Well it is a miracle he ever got back. And, I'm sure, Mr. Treves, under your expert care, he'll have many happy years ahead.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I fear not, Mrs. Kendal. Even in the short time he was gone the size of his head has increased rapidly... as is his pain.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: How awful for John.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: And yet, not once have any of us heard him complain.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Is he... dying then?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes. There is nothing more frustrating, nothing that makes a physician feel more useless, than standing by watching his patient deteriorate. And when that patient is a friend, no... no, there's absolutely nothing I can do.

turns.speaker: KENDAL
turns.text: Well, it's all quite... I've never heard... It's quite...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: You alright?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: y-y-yes--

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: Want to come out?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: You're English.

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: Of course! You want out?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: Won't be a moment.

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: I'm sorry I could only get you a third class ticket, but it's all we had.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh no, my friend...

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: Say hello to London for me. I miss her.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: PLUMED DWARF
turns.text: You know, I saw you once there, in London. You're a great attraction.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: Feeling better now, Mr. Merrick?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: Well, if there is nothing more, I suppose we'll be leaving you now.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: No, nothing.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Merrick.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: What? Oh! I see! It's St. Phillips. Oh, of course. Why... why that's very good, I mean you've gotten the windows and arches just right.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: But it's so good, I mean... it's so very good.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Thank you... very much.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: Where did you get this box?

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: The hallway? Oh, the wastecan!

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I meant no harm, it was the only place where I could find cardboard. I thought it has been thrown away.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: It's alright, it was thrown away. No one wants it. It's just that it's a little dirty, that's all.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: The main spire.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: The... oh, the spire! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Mr. Merrick, where did you learn to do this?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: ...I learned a long time ago.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I'll have to find some more.

turns.speaker: NORA
turns.text: Yes... well, good day, Mr. Merrick.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yyyy... Yyye... yyyess.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes John!

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: ...Yyes

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yyyess.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yyess.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: That's much better. I could understand that "yes".

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Very good! Oh yes! Now listen. I'm going to say some things to you and I want you to repeat them... um... I want you to say them back to me. Do you understand? I'm going to say some things to you and I want you to say them back to me. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Excellent! Now, say... "Hello"

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Hello...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: My name is...

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: My... name is...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John Merrick.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: John... Merrick

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Say "Merrick".

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Merrick...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Say "Mmmerrick."

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mmmerrick.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Say "Mmmerrick."

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mmmerrick.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Well, that's alright. I understand you. Now, say the whole thing again, Hello ...

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Hello... my name is... John Merrick.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Why, my dear Mrs. Mothershead, how good of you to join us. Mr. Merrick, will you please introduce yourself?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Hello, my name is John Merrick.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he maketh me to lie down in green pastures; He leadeth me beside still waters. He restoreth my soul: He Guideth me in the paths of righteousness...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Righteousness...

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Righteousness for his namesake.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Very good, very good. Now, when your visitor comes today I want you to say it exactly the way you said it just now. I will introduce him to you and you will say the words you've learned. If you have any trouble with any of the words, I'll help you. I'm sure you'll be just fine. If you do as well for him as you've done for me these last two days, then I'm sure our visitor will be very pleased. Now, let's go through the whole thing again, shall we? I will say "May I introduce you to Mr. Carr Gomm." And you will say...

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Hello, my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John, may I introduce you to Sir Carr Gomm.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Hello... my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Mr. Merrick likes the food here. Don't you John?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh yes! It is much better than what I am used to.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: ...Yes potatoes... but...

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: But the variety of food here is very pleasing... I commend you.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Why did you let me go on like that, teaching you what you already knew? Why didn't you tell me you could read?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: You did not ask me.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I never thought to ask. How can you ever forgive me?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh, no do not say that. You have been so kind to me. I was afraid to say too much. People always want me to be quiet. You wanted me to speak, but I was afraid. Forgive me.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: We do have a lot to talk about, don't we?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Good evening. How are you feeling?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Good evening. Very well, thank you. And you?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Very well, thank you. I have something for you, John. I'm sure you'll enjoy it, it's very popular.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: This... is my new home?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: The hospital?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Of course! What did you think?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: How long will I stay here?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I promise you. You will never see the inside of that horrible place again. You will never, ever go back to the workhouse... or that man. It's a splendid room, don't you think?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You look splendid, John.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: When one is invited to tea, one must look one's best.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John... what's the matter? John... why are you upset?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I'm not used to such kindness. From a beautiful woman.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Well, it's a lovely bedroom. What do you call that thing above the bed?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: That's a canopy, John.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Ohhh...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: How is your tea, John?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: It's very good. I'm enjoying my visit with you very much. It's so very kind of you to have me as a guest in your home. I'm sorry I made a spectacle of myself.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Not at all, John.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I love the way you've arranged your pictures on the mantlepiece. Is that the way it's done in most houses?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Oh yes.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Who are they of?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Oh, our relatives... the children.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: The children! May I see?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: The Children. Where are your children

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Oh, they're gone for the day... with friends.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Friends. Ah yes, friends! How nice.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Would you... would you like to see my mother?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Your mother?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Good morning, John.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John, there's someone here who would like to meet you. Would that be alright?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: When will the stream be aweary of flowing under my eye? When will the wind be aweary of blowing over the sky? When will the clouds be aweary of fleeting? When will the heart be aweary of beating, and nature die?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Never, oh! Never, nothing will die. the stream flows the wind blows the heart beats Nothing will die.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mr. Treves, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, John?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: ...Can you cure me?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No John, I can't. I can care for you, but I can't cure you.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: I thought as much.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: The cathedral is coming along nicely.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes, soon I will start the main spire, but I must finish these columns first, How kind of her!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: How blind of me. Is there anything else, John, anything at all that I could get for you?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh no! There is nothing! I have everything, you have given me everything I could possibly want. I am happy every hour of the day. I only wish there was something I could give to you.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Please John, it would give me so much pleasure to give you something. Something just for yourself. Isn't there something you would like to have?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: You want a dressing bag, John?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: ...my... home?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, John.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: You did this for me?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Please... please thank the governing committee for me. I will do my utmost to merit their kindness.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: My home.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: There is one more thing, John. Here.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Is it the one you wanted?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Treves. Mr. Treves.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Are you sure? Because I can take it back.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mr. Treves. Thank you my... friends.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mr. Treves! Treves.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: John.... how can you ever forgive me?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Stand up, John. Let them see you.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh no, I couldn't.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: It's for you, John. It's all for you. Go ahead, let them see you.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Will the cathedral be finished soon, John?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes, very soon.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Splendid. it's truly a masterpiece. Well, I suppose I'll be on my way now. I hoped your enjoyed yourself this evening.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh yes! It was wonderful!

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I'm glad, John. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes John?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Mr. Treves, tell me... tell me truly. Is it alright, did I make any mistakes that you can see?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No, John, not one that I can see.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Then I shouldn't change anything?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No, no, I wouldn't change a thing.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Goodnight John. Sleep well.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: You too, my friend. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Ah, Mothershead. How are you feeling today?

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Good. Excellent. Now then, Mrs. Mothershead, I want you to come into this room with me. Inside there is a man with a rather... unfortunate appearance.

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: I've heard.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes... Well, I want you to clear up a little mess, a breakfast tray was spilt. And bring up another breakfast. When you've done that, you and I shall give the man a bath. But, Mothershead, I'm counting on your many years of experience to get you through this, Above all, do not scream, do not cry out, or in any way show this man that you are frightened of him...

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: Sir, you don't have to worry about me. I'm not the sort to cry out. Shall we go in?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes... Yes, let's go in.

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: The workhouse.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes! The workhouse!

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Treves. It'll be his bath-time soon. Has he eaten?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Not quite yet, Mrs. Mothershead. There seems to be some difficulty this morning.

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: Won't come out, eh?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No, he's very upset about something.

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: Just being obstinate, sir. I'll handle it.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: He's had his share of "smacks", Mothershead. I expect that's what drives him under the bed. We must use patience and understanding with this man.

turns.speaker: MOTHERSHEAD
turns.text: Perhaps you've got the time for that, Mr. Treves, I certainly don't. I've got an entire hospital to look after, and you have your real patients. Don't waste your time with him sir, it's like talking to a wall. I don't mean to be harsh, but truthfully what can you do for him? I'll be back later for his bath. And Mr. Carr Gomm would like to see you when you have a moment. Good day sir.
